Here's another trick you may or may not like.
 
As mentioned before, use the same package but different directory for your
test code.  This takes care of the package-protection problem.
 
When you need to access private methods, the trick is this:  Make the
methods package-private instead, and deprecate them.  Then, make sure you
always build your production code with deprecation checking and your test
code without it.  Voila, you can access the method, and production code
cannot--without getting nasty warnings.
 
My colleagues found this too hackish so we never did it this way but I
thought I'd throw it out for your consideration.
 
Kevin

on 1/5/01 4:53 AM, Yongqing Ye at yongqing.ye@... wrote:

> when i write test case for application, normally i group all the testcases
> in one package and application in another package. when i write test case
> for applicaiton method, i encounter one problem:
> some method is private, so testcase can not access it. i have to make the
> method public.
> in C++, we can use friend to solve this problem , but i can not do it in
> java. 
> any solution?

I believe that JUnitX (available at www.extreme-java.de) allows testing of
private methods -- I think that there's some way to use the Java 2 security
features to do so.
